courses.name: Elementary Russian I
courses.description: Five hours of classroom instruction, with one hour lab work weekly. For beginners with no prior knowledge of Russian.

courses.name: Elementary Russian II
courses.description: Five hours of classroom instruction, with one hour lab work weekly.
courses.prerequisites: C- or better in RUSS 1100 or equivalent. or instructor consent

courses.name: Undergraduate Topics in Russian-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and credits may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Undergraduate Topics in Russian-Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and credits may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent. No language credit.

courses.name: Classics and Iconoclasts: An Introduction to Russian Literature
courses.description: Designed to introduce students to some of the major genres, issues, and approaches in the study of Russian literature.  Begins with the most classic of Russian authors, the so-called "father of Russian literature" Aleksandr Pushkin, then moves on to two "classics" from the 19th century (Gogol, Chekhov) and two "iconoclasts" from the first part of the 20th (Mayakovsky, Kharms).  Covers a range of genres, including poetry, short story, and drama, as well as letters, essays and manifestoes.  Course reading list includes secondary essays that both shed light on specific texts/authors as well as provide models for critical and theoretical approaches to literature, with an emphasis on Russian Formalism.  Readings and discussions in English; no knowledge of Russian language or literature required.

courses.name: Classics and Iconoclasts: An Introduction to Russian Literature - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Designed to introduce students to some of the major genres, issues, and approaches in the study of Russian literature.  Begins with the most classic of Russian authors, the so-called "father of Russian literature" Aleksandr Pushkin, then moves on to two "classics" from the 19th century (Gogol, Chekhov) and two "iconoclasts" from the first part of the 20th (Mayakovsky, Kharms).  Covers a range of genres, including poetry, short story, and drama, as well as letters, essays and manifestoes.  Course reading list includes secondary essays that both shed light on specific texts/authors as well as provide models for critical and theoretical approaches to literature, with an emphasis on Russian Formalism.  Readings and discussions in English; no knowledge of Russian language or literature required.

courses.name: Russia: Enigma Wrapped in Mystery
courses.description: Broad introduction to the study of Russia as a discipline; designed to acquaint the student with a wide range of topics connected to the study of Russia.

courses.name: Second-Year Russian I
courses.description: Students will solidify their command of Russian grammar and begin developing their reading skills.

courses.name: Second-Year Russian II
courses.description: Continuation of RUSS 2130.
courses.prerequisites: RUSS 2130 or equivalent, or instructor's consent

courses.name: Between Heaven and Earth: Russian Civilization
courses.description: Survey of Russian culture from the Christianization of the Slavic peoples to late imperial period. No foreign language credit.

courses.name: Between Heaven and Earth: Russian Civilization - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Survey of Russian culture from the Christianization of the Slavic peoples to late imperial period. No foreign language credit.

courses.name: The Arts of Survival
courses.description: Historical, social, and artistic topics. No foreign language credit.

courses.name: The Arts of Survival
courses.description: Historical, social, and artistic topics. No foreign language credit.

courses.name: Russia and America as Comparative Civilizations
courses.description: Analyzes similar developments in the arts, architecture, literature, and film of Russia and America.

courses.name: The Supreme Measure: Capital Punishment in Russian History and Literature
courses.description: Highlights historical, ethical, and religious aspects of capital punishment across the span of Russian history. Provides an opportunity to explore a difficult topic using material unknown to most students; a serious course in literary history. Develops critical thinking skills.

courses.name: The Art of Soviet and Russian Cinema
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 2865) Topics (e.g. Distorted Picture: Post-War Cinema in the Soviet State, Cinema in the Soviet Times and Beyond, etc.) announced at time of registration. Only 6 hours may be taken towards major.

courses.name: The Art of Soviet and Russian Cinema - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 2865) Topics (e.g. Distorted Picture: Post-War Cinema in the Soviet State, Cinema in the Soviet Times and Beyond, etc.) announced at time of registration. Only 6 hours may be taken towards major.

courses.name: Topics in Russian-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Topics in Russian-Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Topics in Russian-Humanities - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Intermediate Russian
courses.description: Normally taken as 5th semester of Russian language sequence.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in RUSS 2160 or RUSS 3160 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Intermediate Conversation and Composition
courses.description: Further develops oral command of Russian as well as listening comprehension and some letter writing skills.
courses.prerequisites: Grade of C- or higher in RUSS 2160 or RUSS 3130 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Heroes of Their Times
courses.description: Examines selected works by the major Russian writers of the first half of the nineteenth century. Reading and lectures in English.

courses.name: Matters of Life and Death
courses.description: Analyzes the major works of Tolstoy and Dostoevsky. Readings and lectures in English.

courses.name: Decline, Fall, and Resurrection in Modern Russian Literature
courses.description: Analysis of the major trends in Russian literature and related cultural developments from 1890 to 1930. Readings and lectures in English.

courses.name: The Split Tree of Russian Literature
courses.description: Analyzes the divided tradition of Russian literature since 1930 in the works of such authors as Nabokov, Pasternak, Bulgakov, and Solzhenitsyn. Readings and lectures in English.

courses.name: Sinners, Saints, and Madmen: 19th Century Russian Literature
courses.description: Introduction to foundational periods (Sentimentalism, Romanticism, Realism and its decline), narratives, and authors of 19th century Russian literary tradition.  Traces development of the "Russian" short story and novel forms, as well as the all-important "Petersburg" theme.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000; sophomore standing or instructor's consent

courses.name: True Fictions: Russian Prose since 1900
courses.description: Survey of Russian prose fiction of the twentieth and early twenty-first century.  During this time Russia experienced a series of drastic changes in society and culture, and as often happens the artists responded more rapidly and insightfully than anyone else.  This was a time of radical experimentation with the very nature of literature, and we will ready and examine some of the fascinating results.  Course gives a short history of Russian prose fiction after 1900, offers a theory of analytical reading of imaginative prose, and hones the skills of intelligent writing about evaluative reading.  Readings, lecture and discussion in English; no previous knowledge of Russian literature is assumed.

courses.name: True Fictions: Russian Prose since 1900 - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Survey of Russian prose fiction of the twentieth and early twenty-first century.  During this time Russia experienced a series of drastic changes in society and culture, and as often happens the artists responded more rapidly and insightfully than anyone else.  This was a time of radical experimentation with the very nature of literature, and we will ready and examine some of the fascinating results.  Course gives a short history of Russian prose fiction after 1900, offers a theory of analytical reading of imaginative prose, and hones the skills of intelligent writing about evaluative reading.  Readings, lecture and discussion in English; no previous knowledge of Russian literature is assumed.

courses.name: Russian Classics I
courses.description: Reading and discussion of selected works by major Russian writers of the nineteenth century. Course conducted in Russian. May be taken before or after RUSS 3640.
courses.prerequisites: RUSS 3130 or RUSS 3160 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Russian Classics II
courses.description: Reading and discussion of selected works by major Russian writers of the twentieth century. Course conducted in Russian. May be taken before or after RUSS 3630.
courses.prerequisites: RUSS 3130 or RUSS 3160 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Russian Women and Film
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 3870 or WGST 3870).  Traces image(s) of the Russian woman in 20th-century Russia as constructed in Russian, Soviet and late-Soviet film.  Discusses heroines of pre-revolutionary melodrama and "new Soviet man and woman" of the 20s.  Considers war-time re-alignment of gender roles in defense of motherland and their subtle revamping in post-war and post-Stalinist period, and the shifting relations between women and men, women and women, and women and the State.  Emphasizes cultural-historical and ideological status of women as reflected in onscreen image(s) in Russian film.  Designed to serve as an introduction to film studies and to 20th-century Russian culture more generally.  Conducted in English (all films have English subtitles).

courses.name: Russian and Soviet Cinema
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 3890). Survey and analysis of selected Soviet films. Emphasis on film-making as a form of art. English or subtitled. Second screenings by arr. Some films may run over 2 hrs. No foreign language credit.

courses.name: Service Learning in Russian Studies
courses.description: Service learning offers students a chance to put into practice what they have learned in theory. Students work as teacher-aids or tutors in foreign language/culture classes at area schools. Does not meet Arts and   Science foundation requirements. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Honors in Russian
courses.description: Special problems in Slavic literature or linguistics.

courses.name: Topics in Russian-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Topics in Russian-Humanities
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Topics in Russian-Humanities - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May be repeated for credit with departmental consent.

courses.name: Intensive Beginning Russian
courses.description: Designed to lead quickly to a reading knowledge of Russian. Cannot be taken to fulfill undergraduate language requirement. Intended for graduate students in other departments who plan to conduct research in Russian.

courses.name: Advanced Russian Conversation
courses.description: Advanced syntax, idiomatic constructions, and vocabulary building.
courses.prerequisites: RUSS 3130 or RUSS 3160 or instructor's consent

courses.name: Special Readings in Russian
courses.description: Special Readings in Slavic literature or linguistics.

courses.name: Russian Poetry
courses.description: Survey of readings in Russian poetry from its beginnings to present.

courses.name: Russian Drama
courses.description: Selected readings in and discussions of major Russian plays of the nineteenth and twentieth century.

courses.name: Russian Drama - Writing Intensive
courses.description: Selected readings in and discussions of major Russian plays of the nineteenth and twentieth century.

courses.name: Russian Prose
courses.description: Explores the development of prose writing in modern Russian letters, paying special attention to native generic designations. Considers dual imagery of realist/naturalist and romantic/fantastic approaches. Studies diverse examples: rasskaz (story), the povest' (tale), the novella, novel essay early 19th c. through 20th c. Considers ways in which literature can itself stand as a philosophical form.

courses.name: The Russian Novel
courses.description: Selected readings and seminar discussion of major novelists of the 19th and 20th centuries.

courses.name: The Art and Life of Pushkin
courses.description: Gives a conceptual thematic overview of Alexander Pushkin's lyrical poetry, as well as some dramatic work and prose. Special attention paid to the parallel development of his artistic and religious beliefs. Poetry read in Russian; prose and dramatic poems in Russian and English.

courses.name: Nikolai Gogol
courses.description: Study of the life and art of Nikolai Gogol. Includes biographical overview, Ukrainian stories, dynamics of folklore, local dialect, and the process of literary creation. Considers St. Petersburg stories, novels, and plays.

courses.name: Dostoevsky
courses.description: Introduction to the works of Fyodor Dostoevsky, including selections from both the shorter works and the major novels.

courses.name: Tolstoy's Fiction and Truth
courses.description: Provides a conceptual overview and analysis of two masterpieces of Tolstoy's art. Acquaints students with the complex and hidden connections between Tolstoy's artistic methods and religious beliefs.

courses.name: Nabokov's Russian Fiction
courses.description: Systematic analysis of Vladimir Nabokov's fiction, both novels and short stories. Emphasis on the artistic properties of prose. Lectures and class discussion in English. Readings in Russian (English translations for undergraduate students).

courses.name: Internship in Russian
courses.description: Supervised introduction to the methodology of the teaching of elementary Russian; conducted in a classroom environment.

courses.name: Blogging the World: The Web in Cultural Context
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 4820. FRENCH 4820). Innovative interdisciplinary course addresses issues of access to international news and specific cultural context working in cross-disciplinary teams. Students in journalism, foreign language, international studies, political science and various other disciplines track cultural developments and information on no-US Web sites, blogs and digital social networks along with exploring various historical forms of communication that preceded the digital era of the Web.  Students analyze the potential and limitations/ effects of blogs and the web in specific contemporary cultural contexts and as part of the broader historical evolution of the web.  The course is taught in English.  The goal of this course is two-fold; students learn the particulars of web blogging, explore various features of the contemporary social network landscape while focusing on the concept of culture, in particular the cultures of Europe and the US.  Questions asked are: what is culture? What is common or popular right now in other cultures? And how do new social networks amplify or alter certain features or culture across national and international contests?

courses.name: Blogging the World: The Web in Cultural Context - Writing Intensive
courses.description: (same as GERMAN 4820, FRENCH 4820). Innovative interdisciplinary course addresses issues of access to international news and specific cultural context working in cross-disciplinary teams. Students in journalism, foreign language, international studies, political science and various other disciplines track cultural developments and information on no-US Web sites, blogs and digital social networks along with exploring various historical forms of communication that preceded the digital era of the Web.  Students analyze the potential and limitations/ effects of blogs and the web in specific contemporary cultural contexts and as part of the broader historical evolution of the web.  The course is taught in English.  The goal of this course is two-fold; students learn the particulars of web blogging, explore various features of the contemporary social network landscape while focusing on the concept of culture, in particular the cultures of Europe and the US.  Questions asked are: what is culture? What is common or popular right now in other cultures? And how do new social networks amplify or alter certain features or culture across national and international contests?

courses.name: Honors Thesis in Russian
courses.description: Intended for Russian majors in their final year of study who have completed the majority of course requirements within the major and are prepared to engage in an independent research project that culminates in a 25-40 page thesis paper.  To be considered for honors thesis, the student should be in his/her final year of the major; must have completed at least three courses in literature, one of which must be at the 4000 level.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.recommendation: Russian major; senior standing, have a minimum cumulative GPA to 3.3, and a GPA of 3.5 or above within the major, and completion of an independent reading course the previous semester (e.g. RUSS 3896; RUSS 4350)

courses.name: Problems in Russian and Slavonic Studies
courses.description: Special problems in Slavic literature or linguistics.

courses.name: Seminar in Russian
courses.description: Course content varies.

Working in cross-disciplinary teams, students in journalism, foreign language, international studies, political science and various other disciplines track cultural developments and information on non-US Web sites, blogs and digital social networks along with exploring various historical forms of communication that preceded the digital era of the Web. courses.name: Distorted Picture
courses.description: (same as FILM_S 7975) Considers strategies and stylistic devices employed by East European and Soviet directors to produce artistically worthy films under censorship.  Discusses how artists adapted methods, boldness of expression, thematic content, and technical sophistication.  Attention paid to production techniques.

courses.name: Research in Russian
courses.description: Translations or creative work not leading to thesis.

courses.name: Problems in Russian and Slavonic Studies
courses.description: Special problems in Slavic literature or linguistics.

courses.name: Thesis Research in Russian
courses.description: Independent research leading to a Master's thesis. Graded on S/U basis only.

courses.name: Topics in 19th Century Russian Literature-General
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Topics in 20th Century Russian Literature
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Russian Intellectual History and Critical Theory I
courses.description: Survey of Russian literary and cultural criticism of the 18th and 19th centuries. Course texts will include representative critical essays as well as selected literary texts. May be taken before or after RUSS 8230.

courses.name: Russian Intellectual History and Critical Theory II
courses.description: Survey of Russian literary and cultural criticism of the 20th century. Course texts will include representative critical essays as well as selected literary texts. May be taken before or after RUSS 8220.

courses.name: Topics in Slavic Linguistics
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: Topics in Slavic Literatures
courses.description: Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.

courses.name: The Art and Life of Pushkin
courses.description: Gives a conceptual thematic overview of Alexander Pushkin's lyrical poetry, as well as some dramatic work and prose. Special attention paid to the parallel development of his artistic and religious beliefs. Poetry read in Russian; prose and dramatic poems in Russian and English.

courses.name: Old Russian Literature
courses.description: Considers the genres, periodization, and development of Russian literature from the beginnings of literacy to the end of the Rurikovich dynasty. Emphasis on literary genres and their evolution. Readings in English or in Russian.

courses.name: Russian Symbolism
courses.description: Study of the history, aesthetics, and creative works associated with the Symbolist movement in Russian literature and art. Primary emphasis on poetry drama, and prose fiction.

courses.name: Pasternak
courses.description: Presents the life-long work of Boris Pasternak in three stages: early, interbellum, and late.  Special attention to the evolution of poetics, with close analysis of selected poems. Includes theory of poetic expression.  Requires a grasp of the main principles of Western versification (prosody, tropes, metaphor, rhyme, euphony), and history of Russian poetry.

courses.name: Old Church Slavonic
courses.description: Designed to familiarize student with the phonological system, inflectional morphology and most important literature of the oldest recorded Slavic language. Comparisons of OCS to modern Slavic languages.
